channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Chavez's heir wins; recount demanded
item.description: Nicolas Maduro, the man Hugo Chavez chose as his successor, wins Venezuela's election, but the opposition candidate calls for a recount, citing irregularities.

item.title: Did Maduro win fair and square?
item.description: Officials in Venezuela say that Nicolas Maduro has won the election, but the opposition is fighting the results.

item.title: Venezuela poll result 'irreversible'
item.description: Nicolas Maduro wins Venezuela's presidential election.

item.title: Maduro calls for peace after vote
item.description: Nicolas Maduro speaks to supporters shortly after he was elected president of Venezuela.

item.title: Opposition candidate urges recount
item.description: Venezuelan opposition candidate Henrique Capriles Radonski urges a recount after Nicolas Maduro is elected president.

item.title: Maduro's path from bus driver to leader
item.description: He began his career as a bus driver in Caracas, and then rose through the ranks to become a member of Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez's inner circle.

item.title: Defector haunted by Kim propaganda
item.description: To the outside world the images from North Korean state television are nearly comical -- weeping soldiers chasing Kim Jong Un into the freezing sea, elderly women screaming as the young leader approaches, and North Koreans unleashing dogs at a poorly made effigy of a South Korean leader.

item.title: Paralyzed anti-war vet's final act
item.description: Tomas Young joined the Army to hunt down the people who caused 9/11. Instead, he ended up in Iraq â€” where he was severely wounded. Back home, he emerged as a vocal anti-war activist. Now he just wants to die.

item.title: Fury at Bieber's Anne Frank comment
item.description: If Anne Frank had not died a teenager in a Nazi concentration camp in 1945, Justin Bieber hopes she would have been his devoted fan.

item.title: Is your old t-shirt harming Africa?
item.description: Inside one of the many busy open markets in Kampala, rows of hanged trousers and dresses swing in midair, casting a shadow over the colorful stacks of unsorted clothes sitting on rickety wooden stalls.

item.title: Rembrandt's 'Night Watch' explained
item.description: Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum, one of the world's best-known galleries, reopens April 13 after a massive 10-year rebuild.

item.title: International hunt for gangster who blasted way out of jail
item.description: Interpol issues an international wanted notice for a notorious French gangster who took hostages and used explosives as part of his brazen escape from prison.

item.title: Hunt for gangster who blasted out of jail
item.description: Police in 26 countries are on the hunt for a French gangster who staged a spectacular escape from jail, taking hostages before using explosives to blast his way out.

item.title: Gangster blasts his way out of jail
item.description: A French gangster is on the run after using explosives to blast his way out of prison. CNN's Dan Rivers reports.

item.title: French gangster's daring jailbreak
item.description: A manhunt is underway for Redoine Faid, who took hostages before blasting his way out of prison.

item.title: Iraq bombings kill at least 25, wound 170
item.description: A series of car bombings across Iraq on Monday killed at least 19 people and wounded more than 130 others, police said.

item.title: Egypt's Mubarak to remain behind bars
item.description: Deposed Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, who faces charges involving the killing of nonviolent protesters during the uprising that brought him down, wants to go free.

item.title: Dozens dead in Somali court attack
item.description: At least 10 heavily armed militants forced their way into a court building Sunday in Mogadishu, Somalia, and launched a deadly attack, according to a local journalist who witnessed the aftermath.

item.title: BBC accused of endangering students
item.description: A BBC journalist who got into North Korea by using a group of students from a top British university as camouflage is facing accusations that he recklessly endangered their safety and damaged the school's reputation.

item.title: China: 60 infected with H7N9 bird flu
item.description: Two more people infected with a rare strain of bird flu in China died over the weekend, as the number of human cases of H7N9 climbed to 60, state media reported Sunday.

item.title: Search for man caught in avalanche
item.description: The search for a missing man who was caught in an avalanche in Washington state over the weekend could resume at first light on Monday, a spokeswoman for the King County Sheriff's Office said.

item.title: Austerity hits global military spending
item.description: World military spending last year fell for the first time in 14 years, with the US share of the global total slipping below 40 per cent.

item.title: Weak yen drives Japan gold rush
item.description: CNN's Diana Magnay reports that a weak yen is spurring many Japanese to trade their gold for cash.

item.title: Fired cop defends Trayvon targets
item.description: The Florida police sergeant fired for possessing shooting targets resembling Trayvon Martin defended himself Sunday and said the targets were meant to be used as training aids for "no-shoot" situations.

item.title: Adam Scott wins historic Masters
item.description: Adam Scott dedicates part of his title to fellow Aussie, Greg Norman, after becoming the first Australian to win the Masters golf tournament in a sudden-death playoff.

item.title: Alonso grabs Chinese Grand Prix win
item.description: Ferrari's Fernando Alonso claimed his first win of the 2013 season Sunday after claiming victory at the Chinese Grand Prix in Shanghai.

item.title: Deftones bassist Chi Cheng dies
item.description: Deftones bass guitarist Chi Cheng died Sunday morning, five years after a car crash left him in a coma, his mother announced. He was 42.

item.title: Pope portrait out of 17,000 condoms
item.description: Alison Kosik talks to an artist who sparks controversy after making a portrait of Pope Benedict out of condoms.

item.title: N. Korea must halt fiery threats: U.S.
item.description: As North Koreans celebrated the birthday of their country's founder, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry urged the regime to ditch its nuclear program and halt its threats.

item.title: Kerry wants real talks on N. Korea
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry discusses North Korea and how the world views the U.S. and guns.

item.title: Japan: N. Korea won't push us around
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry visits Japan on the last stop of an Asian tour that has largely focused on the provocations coming out of North Korea.

item.title: Would Kim Jong Un listen to China?
item.description: If the latest U.S. intelligence reports are true then North Korea is planning to test-fire not one but multiple missiles, the latest provocative act by its unpredictable young leader.

item.title: Brainwashed from birth in N. Korea
item.description: CNN's Brian Todd investigates the indoctrination of children in North Korea's propaganda culture.

item.title: How Korean war might play out
item.description: CNN's Tom Foreman and retired General James Marks map out potential strategies if North Korea attacks South Korea.

item.title: Wearable tech tracks your life
item.description: CNN takes a look at the future of interactive technology.

item.title: The evolution of the cell phone
item.description: CNN's Jim Boulden looks back to the first mobile phone call made 40 years ago.

item.title: Olympic swimmer goes for TV gold
item.description: Anderson Cooper has a preview of Ryan Lochte's upcoming E! reality TV show.

item.title: Are models getting thinner?
item.description: Former fashion editor Kirstie Clements reveals secrets on what models do to stay thin.

item.title: Distraction: Cat walks dog
item.description: Everything is wrong about this. The natural order of things has been disrupted. Run for the hills!

item.title: A beauty beyond skin deep
item.description: As a little girl, she never got a valentine at school parties.

item.title: Cyberbullying blamed in teen suicides
item.description: Online bullying, or trolling, is a disturbing trend that is leading some teens to take their own lives.

item.title: Eurostar takes a cue from air travel
item.description: Eurostar, the high-speed train company connecting London with Brussels and Paris, is undergoing a massive overhaul.

item.title: Tradition of dancing bears in India fade
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the inhumane tradition of bear dancing in India is fading out. Mallika Kapur reports.

item.title: Bourdain: Stories we want to tell
item.description: Anthony Bourdain, the well-traveled chef describes his show as "entertainingly schizophrenic" as it kicks off with a look inside Myanmar.

item.title: Driving alone means more gadget use
item.description: Young drivers are getting the message that distracted driving can be deadly, but a new study released Monday reports drivers ages 16 to 21 put themselves at far higher risk when driving alone.

item.title: Can you cope with criticism at work?
item.description: Criticism from bosses can be hard to swallow. But research shows there are more constructive ways for managers to deliver negative feedback, and that bosses should use positive comments a lot more -- about six times more -- than criticism.

item.title: Visiting Myanmar: 11 things to know
item.description: Even if you're not planning a trip to Myanmar, take notes and fake it as a Burmese travel expert. Click here for advice on mohawks and more.

item.title: Bourdain on fetal duck egg
item.description: Piers Morgan challenges Anthony Bourdain to a taste test of some bizarre foods. Would you join in the challenge?

item.title: Thatcher: Revered and reviled, in life and death
item.description: In the week between her death and her funeral, Britons are having an awkward time coming to terms with the legacy of former PM Margaret Thatcher.

item.title: Rehearsals for Thatcher's funeral
item.description: London gets ready for Thatcher's funeral

item.title: U.S. drone strikes radicalize Pakistanis
item.description: The Sabaoon School for boys in northern Pakistan is anything but average.

item.title: Acid attack highlights Russian ballet battle
item.description: An acid attack on Bolshoi Theater's artistic director has put the spotlight on a battle for control of the world famous Russian institution.

item.title: Why North Korea 'has already won'
item.description: Even if the crisis ends right now, North Korea will have succeeded in sending a message across the world: that nuclear weapons make you untouchable, writes Frida Ghitis.

item.title: A beauty beyond skin deep
item.description: As a little girl, she never got a valentine at school parties.

item.title: 'Happy' Gilmore defies surfing cliches
item.description: Forget Point Break's party animals, modern surfing is more about professionalism.

item.title: How suicide shaped mom's gun views
item.description: I am a mother of three, and my views on guns have evolved significantly over the course of my lifetime. My husband hunts and believes strongly in his right to bear arms. But when my 25-year-old son, Peter, shot himself in a moment of despair in April 2012, I came full circle to a harsh reality: There are almost twice as many suicides as murders by firearm across America, roughly 19,000 of the 30,000 gun deaths each year. Yet we disproportionately fear and almost exclusively talk of criminals in the national gun debate.

item.title: Will we care about Web privacy in 2033?
item.description: The launch of the Facebook Home app has reignited the privacy debate over whether the social networking site is becoming too integrated in our lives.

item.title: Psy lightens mood with new single
item.description: As tensions on the Korean peninsula go up, Psy parties down and releases a new music video. CNN's Anna Coren reports.

item.title: Acid attack shows ballet battle
item.description: An acid attack on Bolshoi Theater's artistic director has put the spotlight on a battle for control of the world famous Russian institution.

item.title: Sunken S. Korean ship on display
item.description: CNN's Anna Coren visits the wreckage of the Cheonan warship, sunk by a North Korean torpedo in 2010.

item.title: Psy lightens mood with new single
item.description: As tensions on the Korean peninsula go up, Psy parties down and releases a new music video. CNN's Anna Coren reports.

item.title: 'Happy' Gilmore defies surf cliches
item.description: Forget Point Break's party animals, modern surfing is more about professionalism.

item.title: Suicide shaped mom's gun views
item.description: I am a mother of three, and my views on guns have evolved significantly over the course of my lifetime. My husband hunts and believes strongly in his right to bear arms. But when my 25-year-old son, Peter, shot himself in a moment of despair in April 2012, I came full circle to a harsh reality: There are almost twice as many suicides as murders by firearm across America, roughly 19,000 of the 30,000 gun deaths each year. Yet we disproportionately fear and almost exclusively talk of criminals in the national gun debate.

item.title: Guatemela's dark chapter
item.description: Decades after the killing of some 1,700 Ixil Mayans, victims testify of torture, rape and death at the genocide trial of a former Guatemalan leader.

item.title: Watch tour guide wrestle python
item.description: People on a tour in the Everglades had a front row seat as their guide wrestled a python.

item.title: Web privacy in 20 years?
item.description: The launch of the Facebook Home app has reignited the privacy debate over whether the social networking site is becoming too integrated in our lives.

item.title: Investigative awards: CNN wins
item.description: CNN has triumphed at the 2012 Investigative Reporters and Editors (IRE) Awards, winning two accolades in the breaking news and multiplatform categories in San Antonio, Texas Wednesday.

item.title: Man hangs from power line, then ...
item.description: Officials say a man in northern China climbed a utility pole, hung on for 15 minutes and then fell without injury.

item.title: Is Egypt on its way to a civil war?
item.description: Egypt's sectarian woes continue after clashes in Khosous and Cairo's main Coptic cathedral. CNN's Ian Lee reports.

item.title: Exclusive: What drives Zlatan?
item.description: The Swedish striker and PSG Player opens up about former coach Pep Guardiola and his time with Barcelona.

item.title: Roman ruins found in London
item.description: Archeologists uncover thousands of ancient Roman artifacts in London. CNN's Erin McLaughlin reports.

item.title: Call girls chase Silicon cash
item.description: Call girls chase cash in silicon valley where newly-minted tech "geeks" are paying not only for love but advice.

item.title: Is your old t-shirt damaging Africa?
item.description: Inside one of the many busy open markets in Kampala, rows of hanged trousers and dresses swing in midair, casting a shadow over the colorful stacks of unsorted clothes sitting on rickety wooden stalls.

item.title: Rare Psalm book may sell for $30M
item.description: A rare copy of the first book printed in what is now the United States of America may sell for as much as $30 million when it comes up for auction in November, according to Sotheby's.

item.title: N. Korea endgame: 3 scenarios
item.description: Hyperbolic North Korean threats of war are not new. What is new is the intensity and persistence of those threats this time around.

item.title: How to fake it as a New York local
item.description: New York: It's the city that gave the world Martin Scorsese, the Ramones and proper bagels (thanks, local tap water).

item.title: Shark steals fisherman's catch
item.description: Fisherman Isaac Brumaghim had a bit of a scare when a shark jumped out of the water and grabbed his fish. KHNL reports.

item.title: Thatcher: Divisive even in death
item.description: In the week between her death and her funeral, Britons are having an awkward time coming to terms with the legacy of Margaret Thatcher.

item.title: Rembrandt's 'Night Watch' explained
item.description: Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum reopens today after a 10-year rebuild. Explore its most treasured masterpiece.

item.title: Scott ends years of pain for Australia at Masters
item.description: Adam Scott made history by becoming the first Australian to win the U.S. Masters -- avenging compatriot Greg 'The Shark' Norman's 1996 defeat.

item.title: Scott wins
item.description: Adam Scott dedicates his title to fellow Aussie, Greg Norman, after becoming the first Australian to win the Masters golf tournament in a playoff.

item.title: Why I fled North Korea
item.description: Hyeonseo Lee says when she was young she thought her country was normal, even though when she was 7 she saw her first public execution.

item.title: Rarely seen North Korea
item.description: The world is used to seeing glitzy military parades from North Korea but defectors paint a very different picture of the country -- one of people making soup out of grass and risking their lives to escape into China.

item.title: U.S. drone strikes radicalize Pakistanis
item.description: Poor boys in Swat Valley are making ready recruits for the Taliban, which is using the specter of controversial U.S. drone strikes to bring new members into its fold. CNN's Nic Robertson reports.

item.title: Defector: I saw first execution at 7
item.description: Growing up, Hyeonseo Lee thought North Korea was the best country, singing a song that she had 'Nothing to Envy.' She watched her first public execution at age 7. Her journey out of North Korea would span 14 years.

item.title: Why North Korea 'has already won'
item.description: Even if the crisis ends right now, North Korea will have succeeded in sending a message across the world: that nuclear weapons make you untouchable, writes Frida Ghitis.

item.title: Defector haunted by Kim propaganda
item.description: To the outside world the images from North Korean state television are nearly comical -- weeping soldiers chasing Kim Jong Un into the freezing sea, elderly women screaming as the young leader approaches, and North Koreans unleashing dogs at a poorly made effigy of a South Korean leader.

item.title: Has N. Korea won?
item.description: World leaders are moving carefully and anxiously, trying to prevent a disaster in the Korean Peninsula. This increasingly unpredictable round of saber-rattling is far from over, but so far the winner is the North Korean regime and the losers are the brutally oppressed North Korean people, joined by much of the rest of the world.

item.title: Adam Scott
item.description: The wearing o' the green has Australian eyes smiling.

item.title: Bird flu
item.description: Two more people infected with a rare strain of bird flu in China died over the weekend, as the number of human cases of H7N9 climbed to 60, state media reported Sunday.

item.title: Black Caviar
item.description: Australian wonder mare Black Caviar extended her unbeaten streak to 25 races in some style on Saturday, blowing away her rivals in the TJ Smith Stakes at Sydney's Randwick Racecourse.

item.title: 'Witch song' storm
item.description: The BBC said Friday it will play a short clip of the Wizard of Oz song "Ding Dong the Witch is Dead" on its pop chart show on Sunday -- not the whole song -- after sales of the tune skyrocketed in the wake of the death of Margaret Thatcher.

item.title: Psy
item.description: Get your dance shoes on. Korean singer Psy, who became a worldwide sensation with his smash hit "Gangnam Style," is making another attempt at a global phenomenon.

item.title: Healthy living in Philippines
item.description: A major housing development in the Philippines tries to combine happy and healthy living. Pauline Chiou reports.

item.title: Reef's beauty captured on film
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Our Oceans: Victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China: 60 bird flu cases reported
item.description: China has two new cases of humans infected with bird flu, bringing the total to 51, state media reported Sunday.

item.title: Zao Wou-ki: Painting beyond words
item.description: The Chinese-French painter Zao Wou-ki once told me that painting expresses the thoughts we struggle to put into words. Faced with this challenge, "It's easier to learn English!" he joked, his wit shining through, even though Alzheimer's disease had already begun its slow, relentless onslaught on his mind.

item.title: Can China convince Kim to cool it?
item.description: As North Korea's long-term ally, analysts say China has the greatest potential leverage over the country's young leader. But is it likely to assert itself and would Kim Jong Un even listen?

item.title: Chinese travelers turn to rail
item.description: With less than half an hour to spare, Chen Zhu calmly emerged from the subway station connected to the massive Beijing West Railway Station with a small, wheeled bag.

item.title: 'Daily Show' clip goes viral
item.description: A "Daily Show" clip mocking North Korea has gone viral in China.

item.title: China's GDP expected to grow
item.description: Despite concerns about debt and export growth, China's GDP could see some growth this year.

item.title: China tourism surge: Your views
item.description: We knew even while researching Tuesday's feature on the global impact of Chinese tourism that the story was likely to generate strong reactions among readers.

item.title: Chinese teen to tee off at Masters
item.description: The legendary Jack Nicklaus may have won the most titles, a 21-year-old Tiger Woods may have been the youngest champion and Gary Player may have made the most appearances, but a little-known Chinese golfer will be added to the illustrious list of Masters record-holders on Thursday.
